elements.content: Amino acid-functionalized Ni4(OH)3Cl tetrahedral clusters containing peptide linkages are linked into hexagonal planes connected pairwise into layers by neutral linkers. These layers stack to afford an open-framework structure, with large cavities occupied by non-ice-geometry (H2O)16 clusters. The layer stacking motif and the guest cluster geometry are both determined by an intricate hierarchy of hydrogen-bonding interactions defined by the array of peptides supported by the tetrahedral units. The (H2O)16 cluster adopts a non-ice-like structure due to the resulting highly symmetrical arrangement of the amide groups around the water molecules and the participation of two hydroxide anions per cluster.

The layer stacking motif and the guest cluster geometry are both determined by an intricate hierarchy of hydrogen-bonding interactions defined by the array of peptides supported by the tetrahedral units. The (H2O)16 cluster adopts a non-ice-like structure due to the resulting highly symmetrical arrangement of the amide groups around the water molecules and the participation of two hydroxide anions per cluster.

elements.content: Organizing water molecules via peptide-like moieties: A Ni4 cluster-based metal organic framework with amino acid derived peptide-like amide linkages has been made. The peptide linkages line the interlayer nanospaces and organize the water molecules within the spaces into a (H2O)16 cluster unit via a hierarchy of hydrogen bond interactions. The 16-molecule water/hydroxide cluster consists of an (H2O)12 unit with a non-ice geometry defined by hydrogen-bonding to the peptides, further favored by the charge-balancing hydroxide anions, and an internal ice-like (H2O)4 unit.

elements.content: Recent work has shown that aspartic acid is capable of binding to metals via two carboxylate groups and the single amino functional group to form extended open frameworks which can be porous and display enantioselective sorption. Peptides formed by amino acid condensation are important in determining the function of a broad range of both natural and synthetic materials. The successful synthesis of amino acid-based open frameworks creates the possibility of using peptides formed by the condensation of amino acids to form open framework materials in which interactions between peptide units and guest molecules are accessible to precise study by small-molecule crystallography. Water interacting with polar atoms in peptide linkages plays an important role in protein folding by facilitating rearrangement of hydrogen bonding as well as enabling catalytic activity of many soluble enzymes. The simplest amino acid derivative with a peptide linkage is pyroglutamic acid, formed by cyclization of the α-amino and β-carboxylate of glutamic acid to afford a five-membered amide ring, leaving the α-carboxylate group accessible for metal binding. Although pyroglutamic acid is not one of the 21 naturally occurring amino acids, pyroglutamate residues at the N-terminus of peptide chains form hydrogen bonds with C-terminal residues of other amino acids within the protein (Figure S12 of the ). These pyroglutamate residues play a vital role in maintaining structural integrity and catalytic activity, and they engage in substrate binding, determining the spatial orientation of the protein via hydrogen bond interactions with other amino acid residues or guest water molecules. Such interactions are critical for the formation of receptor binding conformations and determination of the secondary structure of the proteins. Here we report a material, 1, in which the peptide-containing pyroglutamate anion stabilizes hydroxo-bridged metal clusters, which are then connected by neutral linking molecules (4,4′-bipyridyl) to generate an open framework. The pores within this framework stabilize hydroxide-containing (H2O)16 clusters with non-ice geometries. 1 survives the loss of these guests while retaining crystallinity due to the persistent network of intercluster hydrogen bonds, though the resulting shrinkage and relaxation of the structure prevent the generation of porosity. The intricate water clusters are the outcome of organization of the water molecules in cavities by the amide units in the pyroglutamate peptide bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recent work has shown that aspartic acid is capable of binding to metals via two carboxylate groups and the single amino functional group to form extended open frameworks which can be porous and display enantioselective sorption. Peptides formed by amino acid condensation are important in determining the function of a broad range of both natural and synthetic materials. The successful synthesis of amino acid-based open frameworks creates the possibility of using peptides formed by the condensation of amino acids to form open framework materials in which interactions between peptide units and guest molecules are accessible to precise study by small-molecule crystallography. Water interacting with polar atoms in peptide linkages plays an important role in protein folding by facilitating rearrangement of hydrogen bonding as well as enabling catalytic activity of many soluble enzymes. The simplest amino acid derivative with a peptide linkage is pyroglutamic acid, formed by cyclization of the α-amino and β-carboxylate of glutamic acid to afford a five-membered amide ring, leaving the α-carboxylate group accessible for metal binding. Although pyroglutamic acid is not one of the 21 naturally occurring amino acids, pyroglutamate residues at the N-terminus of peptide chains form hydrogen bonds with C-terminal residues of other amino acids within the protein (Figure S12 of the ). These pyroglutamate residues play a vital role in maintaining structural integrity and catalytic activity, and they engage in substrate binding, determining the spatial orientation of the protein via hydrogen bond interactions with other amino acid residues or guest water molecules. Such interactions are critical for the formation of receptor binding conformations and determination of the secondary structure of the proteins. Here we report a material, 1, in which the peptide-containing pyroglutamate anion stabilizes hydroxo-bridged metal clusters, which are then connected by neutral linking molecules (4,4'-bipyridyl) to generate an open framework. The pores within this framework stabilize hydroxide-containing (H2O)16 clusters with non-ice geometries. 1 survives the loss of these guests while retaining crystallinity due to the persistent network of intercluster hydrogen bonds, though the resulting shrinkage and relaxation of the structure prevent the generation of porosity. The intricate water clusters are the outcome of organization of the water molecules in cavities by the amide units in the pyroglutamate peptide bonds.

elements.content: [Ni32(Cl)8(OH)24(pGlu)24(bipy)24](OH)8(H2O)36(MeOH)12], 1, is formed by solvothermal reaction with nickel l-glutamate as the pyroglutamate source, to afford single crystals, or with l-pyroglutamic acid, to afford enantiopure bulk material. Chiral GC showed that 1 accessed via in situ cyclization of l-glutamate to afford the pyroglutamate found in the framework is racemic, represented here as dl-1. dl-1 can be solved in the space groups R3̅, R3̅m, and R32, with the best solution obtained in R32 with a racemic twin law (see the for a detailed discussion). The chirally pure form, l-1, was grown as microcrystals by using l-pyroglutamic acid directly in the reaction instead of Ni l-glutamate. This sample is phase pure 1 ( shows a Le Bail fit to the powder diffraction data) and homochiral, as determined by GC analysis, but does not contain crystals large enough for single crystal diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

[Ni32(Cl)8(OH)24(pGlu)24(bipy)24](OH)8(H2O)36(MeOH)12], 1, is formed by solvothermal reaction with nickel l-glutamate as the pyroglutamate source, to afford single crystals, or with l-pyroglutamic acid, to afford enantiopure bulk material. Chiral GC showed that 1 accessed via in situ cyclization of l-glutamate to afford the pyroglutamate found in the framework is racemic, represented here as dl-1. dl-1 can be solved in the space groups R3̅, R3̅m, and R32, with the best solution obtained in R32 with a racemic twin law (see the  for a detailed discussion). The chirally pure form, l-1, was grown as microcrystals by using l-pyroglutamic acid directly in the reaction instead of Ni l-glutamate. This sample is phase pure 1 ( shows a Le Bail fit to the powder diffraction data) and homochiral, as determined by GC analysis, but does not contain crystals large enough for single crystal diffraction.

elements.content: (a) Basic building unit of 1: Ni4(OH)3Cl tetrahedral clusters formed by four face-sharing NiO3N2Cl octahedra. Note the μ-3 chloro (green) and hydroxyl bridges (red with yellow H) between the Ni centers. The unique nickel center solely coordinated to hydroxide ligands is shown in purple, while the three nickel centers coordinated to chloride and the cluster-connecting bipyridyl ligands are shown in cyan; one set of coordinating bipyridyls is not represented completely for clarity. Color scheme: (Ni) cyan, purple; (O) red; (N) blue; (Cl) green; (C) gray; (H) white; except the hydrogens of the μ-3 bridging hydroxyl groups are represented as yellow balls. The metal tetrahedron edges are shown with broken lines. (b) Coordination environments of the metal centers in two crystallographically independent Ni4(OH)3Cl clusters in 1. Note that the three nickel centers (Ni(1)) coordinated by the μ-3 chloride are involved in connecting the clusters into an extended layer, while the remaining nickel at the apex (Ni(3)) is not. Similarly, the three nickel centers (Ni(2)) coordinated by the μ-3 chloride are involved in connecting the clusters into an extended layer, while the remaining nickel at the apex (Ni(4)) is not.

elements.content: The structure of 1 is determined by a hierarchy of interactions. The fundamental structural unit is the Ni4(OH)3Cl clustera pseudotetrahedron of four octahedrally coordinated Ni centers is face-capped by three μ-3 hydroxy bridges and a μ-3 chloro bridge to define a triangle and a separate apex of distinct Ni centers (Figure ). There are two crystallographically independent but similar Ni4(OH)3Cl clusters (One is formed by Ni(1) and Ni(3), while the other is formed by Ni(2) and Ni(4)) (Figures b, ). Multinuclear M4O4 metal clusters formed by μ-3 bridging hydroxides have been observed with a variety of ligand systems, including amino acids and lacunary polyoxoanions. The related M4O3Cl cluster is less common but has been formed in Mn2+ and Cu2+ coordination compounds as well as in the extended inorganic network Ni7(TeO3)6Cl2 in 1 the Ni4O3Cl cluster is assembled into an extended solid with organic linkers. The distribution of ligands binding at the two symmetry distinct metal centers within the cluster determines the connectivity of 1.

elements.content: The distinction between the three hydroxide anions and one chloride anion capping the triangular faces lowers the symmetry of the Ni4 pseudotetrahedron (Figures b, ). The resulting polar geometry of the cluster imposed by the distinction between the terminal chloride and hydroxide bridges controls the extended connectivity.

elements.content: The three nickel centers (Ni(1)) coordinated by the μ-3 chloride are involved in connecting the clusters into an extended layer, while the remaining nickel at the apex (Ni(3)) is not (Figure b). All three pyroglutamate anions per cluster coordinate to this unique apical nickel center, which has an oxygen-only coordination sphere consisting of three face-capping hydroxide groups and three edge-bridging bis-monodentate carboxylate groups from the pyroglutamate anions. Three of the six tetrahedral edges of the Ni4O3Cl cluster are thus carboxylate-bridged (Figures and ). The remaining three nonbridged edges comprise the three symmetry-equivalent chloride-coordinated nickel centers and form an equilateral triangular face of the Ni4 unit. Each metal center in this face has a mixed O/N/Cl ligand set, coordinated by two cis bipyridyl linkers, the μ3-chloride, two μ3-hydroxide anions, and a carboxylate oxygen.

elements.content: The octahedral coordination of each metal and the location of the three oxygen (two face-capping hydroxide and one edge-bridging pyroglutamate) ligands within each metal coordination sphere above the basal nickel triangle direct the two bipyridyl ligands beneath the plane and approximately perpendicular to each edge of the triangle (Figure ).

elements.content: The two bipyridyl ligands from each of the three nonbridged edges thus form parallel connectors to three Ni4O3Cl tetrahedra at different heights, thereby forming a buckled three-connected layer created from two vertically separated triangular Ni4O3Cl planes (Figure a)there is no ligand connectivity between the clusters in the planes. Perfect triangular connectivity between the clusters within the layer is enforced by the equilateral triangular basal geometry of the individual clusters. The lower planes of tetrahedra are also oriented to present the non-carboxylate-bridged equilateral basal triangle of Ni centers to the upper plane, permitting connectivity of the Ni4 units via these basal triangles and confining the bipy ligands connecting the planes and the μ3-chloride anions to the interior of the buckled layer (Figure b). The terminal nickel apex of the Ni4O3Cl cluster, and thus the non-network-forming tetrahedral edges bridged by the pyroglutamate units and the hydroxide anions, project from the top and bottom faces of the layer. This buckled layer bounded by pyroglutamate anions is the extended structural unit of 1. The pyroglutamate units are disordered, and this disorder could be modeled.

elements.content: (a) The buckled hexagonal layer in 1 is formed by 4,4′-bipyridyl connectivity of two equilateral triangular planes of Ni4O3Cl units at different heights, indicated by yellow and purple shading. Note that the clusters in the planes are not linked by bipy. The honeycomb layer lies in the ab-plane, and part a shows the c-axis view of this layer. (b) The layer in 1 is corrugated because the bipyridyl ligands connect adjacent Ni4 clusters at different heights along the c-axis. As the three edges of each tetrahedron bridged by pyroglutamate are not involved in the layer formation, they decorate the top and bottom surfaces of the layer, together with the bridging hydroxides, to create a perimeter rich in hydrogen-bonding units. The chloride anions (green) together with the connecting bipyridyl ligands form the interior of the layer. The height of the buckled layer is 7.616(2) Å; the diagonal cross section of the hexagonal channels is 10.391(1) Å × 10.265(1) Å, defined by the nearest C···C separation (the van der Waals radii of the C atom have been considered in the calculation). The hydrogen atoms of the μ-3 bridging hydroxyl groups are shown in yellow.

elements.content: The three-dimensional structure of 1 is determined by the stacking of these layers (Figure ), governed by hydrogen bonding between their external pyroglutamate and hydroxide units (Figure c). Each layer has a large void at the center of the hexagonal space defined by superposition of the two triangular planes (Figure a). This space is partly occupied by Ni4O3Cl clusters from the layers above and below (Figure a)the buckled nature of the layers places the Ni4O3Cl clusters from the upper triangular plane of one layer in an adjacent pair at the same vertical height as the lower triangular plane of the pair defining the succeeding layer along the stacking direction (Figure b). This has two important consequences. First, it locates clusters from next nearest-neighbor layers vertically above each other at the center of the hexagonal void in the intervening layer. There are no O···O or N···O hydrogen bonding contacts between neighboring layers because this next-nearest-neighbor layer interaction is the closest point of contact between the appropriately oriented hydrogen-bonding hydroxide and pyroglutamate groups that bound the layers (Figure ). The two Ni4(OH)3Cl clusters from next-nearest-neighbor layers form six hydrogen bonds via complementary interaction of the pyroglutamate and μ3-hydroxide groups with Ni4(OH)3Cl clusters in next-nearest-neighbor layers (O···O: 3.011(9) and 2.956(4) Ǻ) (Figure c).

elements.content: Successive layers in 1 are related to one another by rotational symmetry and rhombohedral centering as follows: adjacent layers A and B are related by a 2-fold rotation, with layer pairs A′B′ and A′′B′′ generated from AB by the R-translations to give an ABA′B′A′′B′′AB stacking. Note that the layer color coding in this figure is maintained throughout the paper. The white circle indicates the approach of clusters from next-nearest-neighbor layers above (red) and below (green) the hexagonal void of the intervening (blue) layer driven by the formation of the six-point hydrogen bonds between the two clusters shown in Figure c. The relationship between the layer sequence and the space group symmetry is given in Figure S5, together with labeling of the three cavity types. The cavities in 1 are distinguished by color in this representation to show their layered arrangement: the largest cavity (type I) containing the (H2O)16 cluster unitorange (note that there are two hydroxide ions per cavity; calculated from the electron density observed from the single crystal X-ray diffraction data measured at 200 °C); the cavity (type II) containing the water/OH− and methanolpurple (guest composition at RT: [(H2O)14(OH)2] in cavity I and [(CH3OH)6(H2O)4(OH)2] for II); the smallest cavity (type III) formed by six-point hydrogen bonding between μ3 bridging hydroxide moieties and pyroglutamate carbonyl oxygens of tetrahedra from next-nearest-neighbor layersyellow. Several cavities are shown with the actual water molecules instead of the cavity centers.

elements.content: (a) Hydrogen bonded layer formed entirely by the O···O interactions between the water cluster, the carbonyl oxygens of the pyroglutamate, and the bridging hydroxide moieties. Four successive layers coded as in Figure define the type I cavity and locate the guests within it. The pyroglutamate oxygens from the layer on top are shown in blue; the ones from the bottom layer are in cyan, and the Ni4 tetrahedra from the two layers forming the cavity, lying in the plane with the water cluster, are represented as green and purple polyhedra; the white and yellow lines represent O···O hydrogen bonds, with the yellow lines also highlighting the twelve membered ring with the chair conformation present in the water/hydroxide cluster. The water/hydroxide molecules located within the 12-ring are disordered (four molecules occupy eight sites). (b) View perpendicular to the layers, showing the interaction of the pyroglutamate units with the water cluster. The disordered water molecules of the water cluster, sitting above and below the plane of the 12-ring, have not been shown for clarity. Of the six pyroglutamate anions, three come from Ni4O3Cl units from the layer above (blue) the two layers (green and purple in part a) defining the hexagonal cavity and three from the layer below (cyan). The layers forming the cavity containing the water clusters and the bpy units connecting to the nickel tetrahedra shown here have not been shown for claritythey correspond to the green and purple clusters shown in Figure a.

(b) Structure of the water/hydroxide cluster showing the outer 12 membered ring (O-O bonds in yellow, O1W, O2W, and O3W) and the four water/hydroxide molecules present within the cavity formed by the 12-rings (O-O bonds in white, O4W and O5W), forming a (H2O)16 cluster (angles formed by the inner water molecules, O4W and O5W: ∠O4W-O5W-O3W = 111.33°; ∠O4W-O5W-O4W = 119.17°. elements.content: Second, large pseudohexagonal cavities occupied by guest species are defined by the two sets of three Ni4O3Cl clusters from each neighboring pair of layers (Figures and a). The guests in these cavities (denoted types I and II) are located at well-defined positions by hydrogen-bonding to six peptide-derived carbonyl oxygens from the layers above and below the two layers which define the cavities. The positions of these peptide groups are themselves defined by the hydrogen bonding interactions to the μ3-hydroxide anions in the clusters forming the cavity (Figure a). Thus, four successive layers are involved in defining the cavities and arranging the guest molecules within them. The guest molecules do not themselves hydrogen bond to the six cavity-defining Ni4O3Cl clusters, but they are located by groups in the layers above and below these clusters which do (Figure b), due to the hydrogen bond-directed involvement of four successive layers in defining the cavities.

elements.content: The larger of the two symmetry-distinct cavities (cavity I) formed in this manner is occupied exclusively by fourteen water molecules and two hydroxide anions (Figure a), and the smaller (cavity II), by six disordered methanol and four water molecules and two hydroxide anions; the water molecules and the hydroxide anions in cavity II occupy the same site in a disordered manner (O6W in ). Both types of cavities are lined with the chiral carbon atoms from the pyroglutamate units (Figures c and ). As the diffraction data do not permit specific identification of the charge-balancing hydroxides, they are assumed to be evenly distributed between the two classes of cavity (2 hydroxide ions per cavity) in the description that follows, where the cluster is denoted as a pure water cluster for convenience. The (H2O)16 cluster in the larger cavities of 1 consists of two units, an (H2O)4 cluster with an ice-like geometry within an unusual non-ice-like (H2O)12 ring (Figure b and d; ). The six corner water molecules (O2W) of the external chair conformation 12-ring of the water cluster are located by hydrogen bonding to the pyroglutamate carbonyl oxygens (O2W···O8 = 2.836 Å) from six clusters in the layers above and below those defining the cavities, which are in turn located by hydrogen bonding to the hydroxides from the six clusters defining the cavity (Figure b). The O1W and O3W water molecules are located at the midpoints of the edges of the hexamer between the O2W atoms (O1W···O2W = 2.772 Å; O2W···O3W = 2.684 Å) and form unusual almost linear (O2W−O3W−O2W = 179.7°; O2W−O1W−O2W = 174.9°) hydrogen bonds with the corner molecules; in contrast, the angle at the corners of the 12-ring is close to tetrahedral (O1W−O2W−O3W = 110.8°). Thus, the (H2O)12 ring in 1 is markedly different from the other (H2O)12 units described in the literature. The linearity of the O···O hydrogen bonds along the edges of the 12-ring is imposed by the distance between the six water molecules defining the cornersif the angle was tetrahedral, the O···O distance to a water molecule bridging two adjacent corners would be 3.25 Åwhich is in turn set by the hydrogen bond from the six corner water molecules to the pyroglutamate ligands in the layers above and below those defining the cavity (Figure ). Linear O···O hydrogen bonds have been observed in other water clusters, though they are less common than tetrahedral ones, and are observed when hydrogen bonded assemblies are constructed from hydroxide water interactions, thus supporting the coexistence of hydroxide species with water in the construction of this anionic cluster. The eight positions within the 12-ring perimeter are half-occupied by the oxygens O4W and O5W to give an (H2O)4 unit with tetrahedral ice-like geometries generated solely by intracluster hydrogen bonds, defining three eight-membered rings (Figure c). This arrangement of the water is distinctly different from the energetically favored structures for the (H2O)16 cluster, such as the linear fused cube or the fused pentameric structure. Cavity II (Figure ) generated by the interdigitated arrangement between the layers related by R-translation is occupied by water molecules and methanol, both of which are disordered ().

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of 1 shows gradual and continuous weight loss of 7.86% in the 30−200 °C temperature range attributed to complete loss of the guests (calc 7.84%) (), which occurs with retention of bulk crystallinity (Figure ; see for the simulated PXRD of 1). The weight loss in the temperature range 225−600 °C can be attributed to the decomposition of the framework. 1 has ∼15% free volume (calculated using PLATON) after the removal of guest water molecules, but CO2 and H2 sorption measurements reveal no porosity, consistent with the noninterconnected nature of the void space apparent in the Connolly surface representation (Figure a and b).

elements.content: The framework topology of 1 is maintained following the complete desolvation of the single crystal even at 200 °C, and refinement of the single crystal diffraction data from the partially desolvated crystals at 100 and 150 °C and from the completely desolvated one at 200 °C shows significant changes in the cavity sizes at 200 °C (). This is the temperature at which the complete loss of guest water molecules occurs, as evidenced from the TGA (see ), and can be associated with the loss of the hydrogen bonding to the guests.

elements.content: The Ni4O3Cl tetrahedral cluster presented here is comparable to the Ni4O4 type cluster observed in many molecular systems that have been investigated for their interesting magnetic behavior. Few extended coordination polymers incorporating multinuclear Ni-oxo clusters have been reported to date. The dc susceptibility data for 1 () obey the Curie−Weiss law over the 200−300 K range with a Curie constant of 1.22(1) emu K−1 mol−1, indicating an effective moment (μeff) of ∼3.10 μB per Ni(II) and a Weiss constant of 10(2) K. The Curie constant can be explained on the basis of a system of S = 1 spin moments with an average g value of ∼2.2, as is commonly observed for octahedrally coordinated Ni(II) cations in the 3A2 ground statethe 300 K magnetization isotherm obeys the Brillouin function with these values (Figure a).

(b) Inverse susceptibility for the desolvated form of 1. Data collected at 100 Oe are shown, along with a fit to the Curie−Weiss law. For the desolvated sample, a significant temperature independent term (TIP) is required, and the Weiss constant is zero within error.

elements.content: Upon desolvation of 1 (Figure b), the Weiss constant reduces to 1(3) K, and a positive temperature independent term (TIP) of 1.1(1) × 10−3 emu mol−1 is required to obtain a proper fit to the data. However, the Curie constant for desolvated 1 (1.25(4) emu K−1 mol−1) is identical within error to that of the solvated form. The small positive Weiss constants which change upon desolvation are consistent with competition between ferromagnetic coupling associated with the Ni(2)−O−Ni(1) angles (∼93.5°) between the apex and basal Ni, and antiferromagnetic superexchange interactions associated with the Ni(1)−O−Ni(1) angles of ∼116° in the equilateral basal triangle (see and associated discussion).

elements.content: The cyclization of glutamic acid under the reaction conditions prevents the formation of extended dicarboxylate-based nets, as found for the aspartic acid-based frameworks. The single crystals grow from pyroglutamate formed by in situ cyclization and are thus racemic due to scrambling of the chirality during the ring-closure required to form 1. This cyclization affords the peptide units which play a decisive role both in the assembly of four successive layers to give a single water-containing cavity and in determining the structure of the guest water clusters through hydrogen bonding. The tetrahedral cluster building unit is formed from the remaining carboxylate unit of the pyroglutamate and the bridging hydroxide and chloride anions, with magnetism that is expected based on the resulting competing exchange interactions. The μ3-chloride gives the Ni4O3Cl unit two distinct poles, one forming the coordinate bond to the bipy linker to construct the bilayers and the other connecting and arranging those layers by the six-point hydrogen bond shown in Figure c between next-nearest-neighbor layers. Clusters formed by monoacidic amino acids binding solely via their unique carboxylate groups can thus act as building units in extended nets with large pores, occluded here by interpenetration of the buckled bilayers.

elements.content: The arrangement of the stacked cluster-based layers affords a peptide-lined cavity which produces a 16-molecule water/hydroxide cluster consisting of an (H2O)12 unit with a non-ice geometry defined by hydrogen bonding to the peptides, further favored by the charge-balancing hydroxide anions, and an internal ice-like (H2O)4 unit. The structure of the present cluster is thus determined both by interactions with the functionalizing amino acid residues lining the cavities and by intrawater interactions between the guest molecules generating fragments similar to segments of ice. Extended water aggregates are encountered in multicomponent crystals such as biological macromolecules, clathrate hydrates, and framework compounds. The clusters in 1 show an accessible water arrangement when hydrogen bonding to a regular array of peptides contributes to the structure of the water cluster and can be considered in the context of water clusters buried in the vicinity of the active pockets in proteins, while clearly noting that the peptide array is invariably much less regular than that in 1 in these cases. In such protein cavities, hydrogen bonding to guest water molecules occurs both to the peptide backbone and to functional groups in side chains, forming irregularly shaped fused 3-, 4-, and 5-membered rings with non-ice geometries (see ). The N-terminal pyroglutamates in T. aurantiacus xylanase (PDB code: ) and cytochrome c′ (PDB: ) are the closest analogy to the pyroglutamate peptide bonds directing the clusters in 1, as the peptide carbonyls involved in the H-bonding have the same molecular origin in both cases and enforce non-ice geometries on the resulting water clusters (). These irregular water cluster geometries can be attributed to the arrangement of the interacting peptide units and the consequent orientations of the side chain groups around the water molecules. Antifreeze proteins in insects and fish bring about the depression of freezing point by ice growth inhibition by suitably placing hydrogen bonding groups of the amino acids to interact with the ice crystal face, thereby preventing the growth from solution. The shape of the water clusters in 1 can be seen as a simple synthetic analogue of this, where hydrogen bonding of water to a peptide unit forces the interacting water cluster into a non-ice geometry at its periphery (the (H2O)12 subunit) while retaining the ice-like hydrogen bonding motifs in the interior of the cluster, where the guest−guest interactions are dominant, giving the resulting cluster a core (ice geometry)−shell (non-ice geometry) structure. This occurs despite the regular arrangement of peptide bonds in 1.

elements.content: The peptide-based hydrogen bond array that directs the cluster organization remains stable when the water guests are lost, due to the persistence of the six-point peptide−hydroxide hydrogen bonding between tetrahedral clusters from next-nearest-neighbor layers shown in Figure c. 1 is thus stable to the loss of the guests despite the strong interactions which localize them and the absence of connected porosity. This behavior, where guests are lost from isolated cavities without structural degradation, is similar to the observed diffusion of guests through apparently nonporous organic solids and reflects the flexibility and dynamics of the hydrogen bond-connected structure of isolated cavities, permitting 1 to undergo guest loss and then close the windows which allow exit of the guests, forming a stable but nonporous guest-free structure. The structural role of the peptide-to-hydroxide hydrogen bonds is only exerted between next-nearest-neighbor layers (Figures and ), and the less pronounced interactions between neighboring layers may contribute to the ability of the guests to diffuse through the array without the presence of channels connecting the cavities. Frameworks containing peptide bonds are thus interesting targets for future study.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The peptide-based hydrogen bond array that directs the cluster organization remains stable when the water guests are lost, due to the persistence of the six-point peptide-hydroxide hydrogen bonding between tetrahedral clusters from next-nearest-neighbor layers shown in Figure c. 1 is thus stable to the loss of the guests despite the strong interactions which localize them and the absence of connected porosity. This behavior, where guests are lost from isolated cavities without structural degradation, is similar to the observed diffusion of guests through apparently nonporous organic solids and reflects the flexibility and dynamics of the hydrogen bond-connected structure of isolated cavities, permitting 1 to undergo guest loss and then close the windows which allow exit of the guests, forming a stable but nonporous guest-free structure. The structural role of the peptide-to-hydroxide hydrogen bonds is only exerted between next-nearest-neighbor layers (Figures  and ), and the less pronounced interactions between neighboring layers may contribute to the ability of the guests to diffuse through the array without the presence of channels connecting the cavities. Frameworks containing peptide bonds are thus interesting targets for future study.

elements.content:
All reagents were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Single Crystals of the Racemic Form of Ni<sub>32</sub>(Cl)<sub>8</sub>(OH)<sub>24</sub>(C<sub>5</sub>NO<sub>3</sub>H<sub>6</sub>)<sub>24</sub>(C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>8</sub>N<sub>2</sub>)<sub>24</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>36</sub>(OH)<sub>8</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)<sub>12</sub>, <sc>dl</sc>-<bold>1</bold>

Nickel l-glutamate (Ni(C5H7NO4)·2H2O) (1 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridyl (1 mmol), and HCl (0.025 mmol) were dissolved in a 2 mL of water/1 mL of methanol solution and underwent reaction for 2 days at 150 °C under solvothermal conditions. The initial pH of the reaction mixture was 6.2, and the pH of the supernatant after the solvothermal reaction was 5.8. This affords large blue-green crystals (0.1 mm × 0.1 mm × 0.07 mm) suitable for single crystal X-ray structure determination in yields of ∼85% (based on Ni). The crystal was mounted for the single crystal diffraction experiment as soon as it was removed from the mother liquor, in order to prevent the loss of any guest molecules. The sample, which was washed with water and methanol, loses methanol molecules on standing under ambient conditions which are replaced by water molecules from the laboratory air. The microanalysis of the sample left standing under ambient conditions [(microanalysis %, calc values within parentheses): C = 41.80(41.82); H = 4.39(4.46); N = 9.78(9.75). EDAX (%): Ni = 79(80); Cl = 21(20) (EDAX was performed on 8 to 10 large green single crystals of dl-1 using a JEOL 2000FX electron microscope equipped with an EDAX analyzer)] corresponds to the composition Ni32(Cl)8(OH)24(C5NO3H6)24(C10H8N2)24·(H2O)45(OH)8. The volatile MeOH solvent molecules are lost and replaced by atmospheric water during the analysis procedure. We believe that the in situ cyclization of the glutamic acid to a pyroglutamate during the solvothermal synthesis results in the racemization of the product.

Experimental Section

All reagents were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Single Crystals of the Racemic Form of Ni32(Cl)8(OH)24(C5NO3H6)24(C10H8N2)24⋅(H2O)36(OH)8(CH3OH)12, dl-1 

Nickel l-glutamate (Ni(C5H7NO4)⋅2H2O) (1 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridyl (1 mmol), and HCl (0.025 mmol) were dissolved in a 2 mL of water/1 mL of methanol solution and underwent reaction for 2 days at 150 °C under solvothermal conditions. The initial pH of the reaction mixture was 6.2, and the pH of the supernatant after the solvothermal reaction was 5.8. This affords large blue-green crystals (0.1 mm × 0.1 mm × 0.07 mm) suitable for single crystal X-ray structure determination in yields of ~85% (based on Ni). The crystal was mounted for the single crystal diffraction experiment as soon as it was removed from the mother liquor, in order to prevent the loss of any guest molecules. The sample, which was washed with water and methanol, loses methanol molecules on standing under ambient conditions which are replaced by water molecules from the laboratory air. The microanalysis of the sample left standing under ambient conditions [(microanalysis %, calc values within parentheses): C = 41.80(41.82); H = 4.39(4.46); N = 9.78(9.75). EDAX (%): Ni = 79(80); Cl = 21(20) (EDAX was performed on 8 to 10 large green single crystals of dl-1 using a JEOL 2000FX electron microscope equipped with an EDAX analyzer)] corresponds to the composition Ni32(Cl)8(OH)24(C5NO3H6)24(C10H8N2)24⋅(H2O)45(OH)8. The volatile MeOH solvent molecules are lost and replaced by atmospheric water during the analysis procedure. We believe that the in situ cyclization of the glutamic acid to a pyroglutamate during the solvothermal synthesis results in the racemization of the product.

elements.content: 0.0465 g of NiCO3 and 0.051 g of l-pyroglutamic acid were dissolved in a 1 mL of methanol/2 mL of water mixture, and to this solution was added 0.065 g of 4,4′-bipyridyl (bipy) under continuous stirring. The pH was raised from 5.0 to 8.5 using 90 μL of 1 M NaOH, and then the pH was carefully lowered to 7.2 by adding 20 μL of 1 M HCl. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 150 °C for 18 h under solvothermal conditions. The product blue-green microcrystals were washed with copious amounts of deionized water and methanol. Bulk chirality from GC (ee): 94%.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Bulk Homochiral 1 

0.0465 g of NiCO3 and 0.051 g of l-pyroglutamic acid were dissolved in a 1 mL of methanol/2 mL of water mixture, and to this solution was added 0.065 g of 4,4'-bipyridyl (bipy) under continuous stirring. The pH was raised from 5.0 to 8.5 using 90 μL of 1 M NaOH, and then the pH was carefully lowered to 7.2 by adding 20 μL of 1 M HCl. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 150 °C for 18 h under solvothermal conditions. The product blue-green microcrystals were washed with copious amounts of deionized water and methanol. Bulk chirality from GC (ee): 94%.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector for structure solution at room temperature. The variable temperature single crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out at station 9.8 of the Synchrotron Radiation Source, Daresbury Laboratory. Suitable single crystals were mounted on a glass fiber, and X-ray diffraction was performed on crystals which were heated to 100, 150, and 200 °C on a Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream 700+ series (data at 100 and 150 °C were collected on the same crystal, but the data at 200 °C were from a different crystal of the same batch). The sample temperature was allowed to equilibrate for 30 min at every temperature step before the diffraction experiment.
elements.clean_text:
Measurement Details

Single crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector for structure solution at room temperature. The variable temperature single crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out at station 9.8 of the Synchrotron Radiation Source, Daresbury Laboratory. Suitable single crystals were mounted on a glass fiber, and X-ray diffraction was performed on crystals which were heated to 100, 150, and 200 °C on a Oxford Cryosystems Cryostream 700+ series (data at 100 and 150 °C were collected on the same crystal, but the data at 200 °C were from a different crystal of the same batch). The sample temperature was allowed to equilibrate for 30 min at every temperature step before the diffraction experiment.

elements.content: The structure could be solved in three different space groups (R3̅, R3̅m, and R32). A check for addition symmetry on the solution obtained in the R32 setting (with a racemic twin law), done using PLATON, indicated the possibility of a solution in R3̅m. Hence, the structure was solved in all three space group settings. However, the final refinement statistics (R32 (with a regular racemic twin law): R 1 = 0.0420; wR 2 = 0.1187; GOF = 1.076. R3̅: R 1 = 0.0511; wR 2 = 0.1305; GOF = 1.101. R3̅m: R 1 = 0.0631; wR 2 = 0.1736; GOF = 1.101) suggested the R32 with a racemic twin law to be the best solution. Also, the solution was checked for any additional merohedral twinning using ROTAX, and none was found.

elements.content: The refinement of the single crystal X-ray data with a racemic twin law yielded a batch scale factor value of 0.51 (esd: 0.03), indicating that the single crystals obtained from the synthesis presented in the paper were racemically twinned. i.e. an intergrowth of unit cells consisting solely of the S-enantiomer of pyroglutamate with those consisting solely of the R-enantiomer in equal proportions within experimental error in this case. The chirally pure powder sample, prepared from chirally pure pyroglutamate, presumably consists of the same structure but with only one hand of the unit cell present, though the absence of sufficiently sized crystals for single crystal diffraction prevents the direct testing of this hypothesis.

elements.content:
X-ray powder diffraction data were collected in transmission geometry using a Stoe Stadi-P diffractometer with Cu Kα1 radiation.

TGA data were recorded using a Seiko S-II instrument.

GC Measurements

Determination of the bulk chirality of the framework, 1: The pyroglutamate anions were extracted from the bulk material in the pyroglutamic acid (pGlu) form by adding 1 M NaOH (4 mL) to the framework (∼30 mg) and removing the resulting precipitate by filtration through a small plug of cotton wool. The addition of NaOH to the framework results in the precipitation of Ni(OH)2 and the 4,4′-bipyridyl linking ligands. Removal of the solids leaves sodium pyroglutamate in the filtrate. The filtrate is neutralized by the addition of 1 M HCl and the aqueous solution removed by rotary evaporation. The resulting white solid is a mixture of pGlu (1H NMR) and NaCl (generated by the neutralization step), as confirmed by elemental analysis.

GC Measurements

Determination of the bulk chirality of the framework, 1: The pyroglutamate anions were extracted from the bulk material in the pyroglutamic acid (pGlu) form by adding 1 M NaOH (4 mL) to the framework (~30 mg) and removing the resulting precipitate by filtration through a small plug of cotton wool. The addition of NaOH to the framework results in the precipitation of Ni(OH)2 and the 4,4'-bipyridyl linking ligands. Removal of the solids leaves sodium pyroglutamate in the filtrate. The filtrate is neutralized by the addition of 1 M HCl and the aqueous solution removed by rotary evaporation. The resulting white solid is a mixture of pGlu (1H NMR) and NaCl (generated by the neutralization step), as confirmed by elemental analysis.

elements.content: Once the pGlu has been recovered from the bulk framework sample, it is necessary to derivatize this prior to GC analysis. The carboxylic acid groups are first converted to ethyl esters by heating in ethanol (5 mL) and HCl (4 M, 1 mL) in a 20 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a condenser for 1 h. The NaCl present in the mixture does not interfere with the derivatization procedure and is not removed until the very end when the pGlu(OEt) derivative is dissolved in ethanol and the NaCl is filtered off. The solution concentration for GC analysis is 0.5% (w/v) pGlu(OEt) in ethanol.

elements.content: GC analysis was carried out using a valine-based Chirasil-Val capillary-GC column (length 25 m, inner diameter 0.3 mm, outer diameter 0.40 mm) supplied by Alltech. All enantiomeric separations were carried out using the following conditions: carrier gas, 0.5 bar He; detector, FID 220 °C; injector, 220 °C. The temperature program involved: initial temperature = 100 °C; final temperature = 190 °C; and heating rate = 3 °C/min. Peaks were separated with baseline resolution under these conditions.

cln_elements.content:
All reagents were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Single Crystals of the Racemic Form of Ni<sub>32</sub>(Cl)<sub>8</sub>(OH)<sub>24</sub>(C<sub>5</sub>NO<sub>3</sub>H<sub>6</sub>)<sub>24</sub>(C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>8</sub>N<sub>2</sub>)<sub>24</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>36</sub>(OH)<sub>8</sub>(CH<sub>3</sub>OH)<sub>12</sub>, <sc>dl</sc>-<bold>1</bold>

Nickel l-glutamate (Ni(C5H7NO4)·2H2O) (1 mmol), 4,4′-bipyridyl (1 mmol), and HCl (0.025 mmol) were dissolved in a 2 mL of water/1 mL of methanol solution and underwent reaction for 2 days at 150 °C under solvothermal conditions. The initial pH of the reaction mixture was 6.2, and the pH of the supernatant after the solvothermal reaction was 5.8. This affords large blue-green crystals (0.1 mm × 0.1 mm × 0.07 mm) suitable for single crystal X-ray structure determination in yields of ∼85% (based on Ni). The crystal was mounted for the single crystal diffraction experiment as soon as it was removed from the mother liquor, in order to prevent the loss of any guest molecules. The sample, which was washed with water and methanol, loses methanol molecules on standing under ambient conditions which are replaced by water molecules from the laboratory air. The microanalysis of the sample left standing under ambient conditions [(microanalysis %, calc values within parentheses): C = 41.80(41.82); H = 4.39(4.46); N = 9.78(9.75). EDAX (%): Ni = 79(80); Cl = 21(20) (EDAX was performed on 8 to 10 large green single crystals of dl-1 using a JEOL 2000FX electron microscope equipped with an EDAX analyzer)] corresponds to the composition Ni32(Cl)8(OH)24(C5NO3H6)24(C10H8N2)24·(H2O)45(OH)8. The volatile MeOH solvent molecules are lost and replaced by atmospheric water during the analysis procedure. We believe that the in situ cyclization of the glutamic acid to a pyroglutamate during the solvothermal synthesis results in the racemization of the product.

Synthesis of Bulk Homochiral <bold>1</bold>

0.0465 g of NiCO3 and 0.051 g of l-pyroglutamic acid were dissolved in a 1 mL of methanol/2 mL of water mixture, and to this solution was added 0.065 g of 4,4′-bipyridyl (bipy) under continuous stirring. The pH was raised from 5.0 to 8.5 using 90 μL of 1 M NaOH, and then the pH was carefully lowered to 7.2 by adding 20 μL of 1 M HCl. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 150 °C for 18 h under solvothermal conditions. The product blue-green microcrystals were washed with copious amounts of deionized water and methanol. Bulk chirality from GC (ee): 94%.

Experimental Section

All reagents were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Single Crystals of the Racemic Form of Ni32(Cl)8(OH)24(C5NO3H6)24(C10H8N2)24⋅(H2O)36(OH)8(CH3OH)12, dl-1 

Nickel l-glutamate (Ni(C5H7NO4)⋅2H2O) (1 mmol), 4,4'-bipyridyl (1 mmol), and HCl (0.025 mmol) were dissolved in a 2 mL of water/1 mL of methanol solution and underwent reaction for 2 days at 150 °C under solvothermal conditions. The initial pH of the reaction mixture was 6.2, and the pH of the supernatant after the solvothermal reaction was 5.8. This affords large blue-green crystals (0.1 mm × 0.1 mm × 0.07 mm) suitable for single crystal X-ray structure determination in yields of ~85% (based on Ni). The crystal was mounted for the single crystal diffraction experiment as soon as it was removed from the mother liquor, in order to prevent the loss of any guest molecules. The sample, which was washed with water and methanol, loses methanol molecules on standing under ambient conditions which are replaced by water molecules from the laboratory air. The microanalysis of the sample left standing under ambient conditions [(microanalysis %, calc values within parentheses): C = 41.80(41.82); H = 4.39(4.46); N = 9.78(9.75). EDAX (%): Ni = 79(80); Cl = 21(20) (EDAX was performed on 8 to 10 large green single crystals of dl-1 using a JEOL 2000FX electron microscope equipped with an EDAX analyzer)] corresponds to the composition Ni32(Cl)8(OH)24(C5NO3H6)24(C10H8N2)24⋅(H2O)45(OH)8. The volatile MeOH solvent molecules are lost and replaced by atmospheric water during the analysis procedure. We believe that the in situ cyclization of the glutamic acid to a pyroglutamate during the solvothermal synthesis results in the racemization of the product.

Synthesis of Bulk Homochiral 1 

0.0465 g of NiCO3 and 0.051 g of l-pyroglutamic acid were dissolved in a 1 mL of methanol/2 mL of water mixture, and to this solution was added 0.065 g of 4,4'-bipyridyl (bipy) under continuous stirring. The pH was raised from 5.0 to 8.5 using 90 μL of 1 M NaOH, and then the pH was carefully lowered to 7.2 by adding 20 μL of 1 M HCl. The resulting mixture was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 150 °C for 18 h under solvothermal conditions. The product blue-green microcrystals were washed with copious amounts of deionized water and methanol. Bulk chirality from GC (ee): 94%.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analysis of 1 shows gradual and continuous weight loss of 7.86% in the 30−200 °C temperature range attributed to complete loss of the guests (calc 7.84%) (), which occurs with retention of bulk crystallinity (Figure ; see for the simulated PXRD of 1). The weight loss in the temperature range 225−600 °C can be attributed to the decomposition of the framework. 1 has ∼15% free volume (calculated using PLATON) after the removal of guest water molecules, but CO2 and H2 sorption measurements reveal no porosity, consistent with the noninterconnected nature of the void space apparent in the Connolly surface representation (Figure a and b).

The Ni4O3Cl tetrahedral cluster presented here is comparable to the Ni4O4 type cluster observed in many molecular systems that have been investigated for their interesting magnetic behavior. Few extended coordination polymers incorporating multinuclear Ni-oxo clusters have been reported to date. The dc susceptibility data for 1 () obey the Curie−Weiss law over the 200−300 K range with a Curie constant of 1.22(1) emu K−1 mol−1, indicating an effective moment (μeff) of ∼3.10 μB per Ni(II) and a Weiss constant of 10(2) K. The Curie constant can be explained on the basis of a system of S = 1 spin moments with an average g value of ∼2.2, as is commonly observed for octahedrally coordinated Ni(II) cations in the 3A2 ground statethe 300 K magnetization isotherm obeys the Brillouin function with these values (Figure a).

cln_elements.content: (a) Basic building unit of 1: Ni4(OH)3Cl tetrahedral clusters formed by four face-sharing NiO3N2Cl octahedra. Note the μ-3 chloro (green) and hydroxyl bridges (red with yellow H) between the Ni centers. The unique nickel center solely coordinated to hydroxide ligands is shown in purple, while the three nickel centers coordinated to chloride and the cluster-connecting bipyridyl ligands are shown in cyan; one set of coordinating bipyridyls is not represented completely for clarity. Color scheme: (Ni) cyan, purple; (O) red; (N) blue; (Cl) green; (C) gray; (H) white; except the hydrogens of the μ-3 bridging hydroxyl groups are represented as yellow balls. The metal tetrahedron edges are shown with broken lines. (b) Coordination environments of the metal centers in two crystallographically independent Ni4(OH)3Cl clusters in 1. Note that the three nickel centers (Ni(1)) coordinated by the μ-3 chloride are involved in connecting the clusters into an extended layer, while the remaining nickel at the apex (Ni(3)) is not. Similarly, the three nickel centers (Ni(2)) coordinated by the μ-3 chloride are involved in connecting the clusters into an extended layer, while the remaining nickel at the apex (Ni(4)) is not.

cln_elements.content: (a) The buckled hexagonal layer in 1 is formed by 4,4′-bipyridyl connectivity of two equilateral triangular planes of Ni4O3Cl units at different heights, indicated by yellow and purple shading. Note that the clusters in the planes are not linked by bipy. The honeycomb layer lies in the ab-plane, and part a shows the c-axis view of this layer. (b) The layer in 1 is corrugated because the bipyridyl ligands connect adjacent Ni4 clusters at different heights along the c-axis. As the three edges of each tetrahedron bridged by pyroglutamate are not involved in the layer formation, they decorate the top and bottom surfaces of the layer, together with the bridging hydroxides, to create a perimeter rich in hydrogen-bonding units. The chloride anions (green) together with the connecting bipyridyl ligands form the interior of the layer. The height of the buckled layer is 7.616(2) Å; the diagonal cross section of the hexagonal channels is 10.391(1) Å × 10.265(1) Å, defined by the nearest C···C separation (the van der Waals radii of the C atom have been considered in the calculation). The hydrogen atoms of the μ-3 bridging hydroxyl groups are shown in yellow.

cln_elements.content: Successive layers in 1 are related to one another by rotational symmetry and rhombohedral centering as follows: adjacent layers A and B are related by a 2-fold rotation, with layer pairs A′B′ and A′′B′′ generated from AB by the R-translations to give an ABA′B′A′′B′′AB stacking. Note that the layer color coding in this figure is maintained throughout the paper. The white circle indicates the approach of clusters from next-nearest-neighbor layers above (red) and below (green) the hexagonal void of the intervening (blue) layer driven by the formation of the six-point hydrogen bonds between the two clusters shown in Figure c. The relationship between the layer sequence and the space group symmetry is given in Figure S5, together with labeling of the three cavity types. The cavities in 1 are distinguished by color in this representation to show their layered arrangement: the largest cavity (type I) containing the (H2O)16 cluster unitorange (note that there are two hydroxide ions per cavity; calculated from the electron density observed from the single crystal X-ray diffraction data measured at 200 °C); the cavity (type II) containing the water/OH− and methanolpurple (guest composition at RT: [(H2O)14(OH)2] in cavity I and [(CH3OH)6(H2O)4(OH)2] for II); the smallest cavity (type III) formed by six-point hydrogen bonding between μ3 bridging hydroxide moieties and pyroglutamate carbonyl oxygens of tetrahedra from next-nearest-neighbor layersyellow. Several cavities are shown with the actual water molecules instead of the cavity centers.

cln_elements.content: (a) Rotation of the connecting bipyridyl ligands by 60° between neighboring layers results in the centroid of the six ring in one layer being blocked by half of the Ni4O3Cl units in the neighboring layer. The layer coloring scheme used is the same as that in Figure . (b) The buckled nature of the layers results in the Ni4O3Cl unit occupying the cavity centroid being located at the same height along the stacking direction as one of the two planes of Ni4O3Cl units in the layer forming the hexagonal cavity, indicated by highlighting of one tetrahedron (orange and cyan) in each layer here. (c) Hydroxide-pyroglutamate hydrogen bonding between Ni4O3Cl clusters in next-nearest-neighbor layers, represented with the layer-coloring scheme of Figure . Clusters from the red and green layers are aligned over the center of the hexagonal voids in the intervening blue layer (Figure ). This forms a small spherical cavity (diameter 1.159 Å considering the van der Waals radii of the C atom), devoid of guest species (cavity III, represented by yellow spheres in Figure ). The hydrogen atoms of the μ-3 bridging hydroxyl groups are shown in yellow.

cln_elements.content: (a) Hydrogen bonded layer formed entirely by the O···O interactions between the water cluster, the carbonyl oxygens of the pyroglutamate, and the bridging hydroxide moieties. Four successive layers coded as in Figure define the type I cavity and locate the guests within it. The pyroglutamate oxygens from the layer on top are shown in blue; the ones from the bottom layer are in cyan, and the Ni4 tetrahedra from the two layers forming the cavity, lying in the plane with the water cluster, are represented as green and purple polyhedra; the white and yellow lines represent O···O hydrogen bonds, with the yellow lines also highlighting the twelve membered ring with the chair conformation present in the water/hydroxide cluster. The water/hydroxide molecules located within the 12-ring are disordered (four molecules occupy eight sites). (b) View perpendicular to the layers, showing the interaction of the pyroglutamate units with the water cluster. The disordered water molecules of the water cluster, sitting above and below the plane of the 12-ring, have not been shown for clarity. Of the six pyroglutamate anions, three come from Ni4O3Cl units from the layer above (blue) the two layers (green and purple in part a) defining the hexagonal cavity and three from the layer below (cyan). The layers forming the cavity containing the water clusters and the bpy units connecting to the nickel tetrahedra shown here have not been shown for claritythey correspond to the green and purple clusters shown in Figure a.

cln_elements.content: (a) Cavity I is formed by interdigitation between two successive layers and is occupied by an (H2O)16 water cluster (the cluster is represented as an (H2O)20 unit (see Figure S6) because of disorder within the internal water molecules. Two of the 16 occupied positions are taken by hydroxide anions. (b) Structure of the water/hydroxide cluster showing the outer 12 membered ring (O−O bonds in yellow, O1W, O2W, and O3W) and the four water/hydroxide molecules present within the cavity formed by the 12-rings (O−O bonds in white, O4W and O5W), forming a (H2O)16 cluster (angles formed by the inner water molecules, O4W and O5W: ∠O4W−O5W−O3W = 111.33°; ∠O4W−O5W−O4W = 119.17°. (c) (H2O)16 water/hydroxide cluster showing the three eight-rings formed by the four water molecules within the 12-ring.

cln_elements.content: (a) Connolly surface representation of 1. The cavities, shown in cyan with a gray surface, are isolated with no direct interconnection. (b) View perpendicular to the layers of 1 showing the isolated cavities. (c) Enlarged view of cavity I viewed along the b-axis. The red regions indicate the framework, while the pores are represented in blue. The chiral C-atoms of the pyroglutamate unit lining the inner surface of the pore are shown as gray spheres.

cln_elements.content: (a) Powder XRD of 1, before and after resolvation of the desolvated sample by exposing it to air (desolvated by heating until 225 °C on a TGA). The inset shows the loss of solvent measured on the TGA. Purple = as made; blue = heated until 225 °C. As made: a = 20.764(4); c = 44.224(8) Å; volume 16512.5(63) Å3; FOM = 60. Evacuated: a = 20.901(9); c = 43.483(15) Å; volume: 16451.1(129) Å3; FOM: 33. (b) Comparison of the powder XRD pattern of as made 1 and a sample evacuated on a Schlenk line by heating at 150 °C for 18 h and sealing in a capillary under He in a glovebox. Purple = as made; blue = evacuated. The change in the lattice parameters due to guest loss (e.g., 1.7% decrease in c on desolvation, 0.66% increase in a) shows that 1 undergoes significant structural changes on desolvation, in agreement with the single crystal XRD data reported in the Supporting Information.

cln_elements.content: (a) Magnetization versus field at 300 K for solvated 1. Results for the Brillouin function with S = 1 and g = 2.22 are shown, which agree well with the data. (b) Inverse susceptibility for the desolvated form of 1. Data collected at 100 Oe are shown, along with a fit to the Curie−Weiss law. For the desolvated sample, a significant temperature independent term (TIP) is required, and the Weiss constant is zero within error.

metadata.title: Guest Organization by an Amino Acid-Derived Amide Linkage in a Cluster-Based Open Framework
